G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, *Sarah Thompson* (“Mother”), pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209, § 37; and the equitable powers of this Honorable Court, and respectfully petitions this Court to modify the existing custody order entered on **May 15, 2018**, in the above-captioned matter, regarding the parties’ minor child, **Emily Johnson (age 10)**.

G.L. c. 209, \u00a7 37.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, *Sarah Thompson* (“Mother”), pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209, § 37; and the equitable powers of this Honorable Court, and respectfully petitions this Court to modify the existing custody order entered on **May 15, 2018**, in the above-captioned matter, regarding the parties’ minor child, **Emily Johnson (age 10)**.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over the subject matter and the parties pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 215, § 6.

G.L. c. 209B.proposition: The Massachusetts Child Custody Jurisdiction Act, G.L. c. 209B, confirms this Court’s continuing jurisdiction to modify existing custody judgments for children who reside in Massachusetts.

*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.proposition: The “best interests of the child” is the **paramount consideration** in all custody determinations.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.support_reasoning: The court explicitly states that in removal and custody-related determinations, “the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern.” The opinion frames its analysis of both custody and removal under a best-interests standard, making clear that this is the controlling, paramount consideration in such determinations. Thus it directly supports the proposition as to custody determinations generally.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.relevant_excerpt: “As most recently reformulated by the Supreme Court of New Jersey in Cooper v. Cooper, 99 N.J. 42 (1984), the ‘real advantage’ test is grounded on the ‘realization that after a divorce a child’s subsequent relationship with both parents can never be the same as before the divorce . . . [and] that the child’s quality of life and style of life are provided by the custodial parent.’ Id. at 53. Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Courts have consistently held that custody modifications are warranted when the original circumstances have meaningfully changed and continuing the existing order would not serve the child’s welfare.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The case is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a generic custody‑modification standard case. The court applies a best‑interests analysis triggered by a relocation request in a joint physical custody context and expressly relies on the ALI principle that relocation can constitute a substantial change in circumstances, but it does not hold or discuss that custody modifications are warranted whenever original circumstances have meaningfully changed and the existing order no longer serves the child’s welfare. The focus is on whether to authorize removal, not on when to modify custody based on changed circumstances generally.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
“The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002)… state in pertinent part:
‘(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances… only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce]…
“(4)… the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests… taking into account all relevant factors including the effects of the relocation on the child.’”

*Custody of Kale*, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 708.proposition: Courts have consistently held that custody modifications are warranted when the original circumstances have meaningfully changed and continuing the existing order would not serve the child’s welfare.
*Custody of Kale*, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 708.support_reasoning: The opinion in Custody of Kale is not about custody at all; it is a criminal appeal from rape and indecent assault convictions. The court does not discuss standards for modifying custody orders, changed circumstances, or child welfare in the context of custody determinations. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition regarding custody modifications based on changed circumstances and the child’s welfare.

*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.proposition: The Court’s analysis focuses on whether modification will promote the child’s emotional, physical, and developmental well‑being.
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.support_reasoning: The court frames the governing standard as the child’s welfare, happiness, and probable future, and upholds the custody/visitation determination based on findings about the child’s emotional and physical reactions to the parents’ conflict, and the father and stepmother’s care of her physical and emotional needs. While the opinion uses the general "welfare of the child" formulation rather than the exact triad "emotional, physical, and developmental well‑being," its reasoning focuses on those substantive aspects of the child’s well‑being in deciding that the custody arrangement (and thus any modification) is appropriate.
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.relevant_excerpt: There were captures and recaptures of the child in New York and Boston in circumstances which were harmful to the child and which caused emotional and physical reactions in the child commensurate with these distresses… The father and stepmother have become the dominant custodians of the child, caring for her physical and emotional needs, and the child has responded well in spite of the controversy over her… In providing for the custody of a minor child… the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration… in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future.

*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (198.proposition: In considering the child’s expressed preference, particularly where a child demonstrates maturity, the Court may weigh the child’s wishes as one of several relevant factors.
*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (198.support_reasoning: The court explicitly discusses how to treat Tony’s stated preference, noting that at his age it is not decisive but is one factor among others in the best-interests analysis. It then weighs his wishes alongside other considerations such as his adjustment to school, relationship with his sister, and existing support system. This directly supports the proposition that a child’s expressed preference, especially where the child shows maturity, may be considered as one of several relevant factors rather than being controlling.
*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608 (198.relevant_excerpt: “Tony’s custody presents a closer question. His father appears to have indoctrinated him with some dislike for his mother, and he has expressed a preference for Bielefeld. … The preference of someone Tony’s age (ten at the time of the proceedings) is not given decisive weight, although it is a factor to be considered. … [The family service officer] found Tony to be ‘a very bright, honest, and articulate 9-year old’ who, although he wishes to return to Germany, ‘has adapted well to his new school’ in Amherst….”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Improved stability or parental fitness, acquired after the entry of the prior order, may constitute a material change justifying modification.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss the statutory requirement of a “material and substantial change in circumstances” to justify modifying custody, but it does not treat improved stability or increased parental fitness after the prior order as a qualifying change. Instead, the court finds that the supposed changes (including the child’s adjustment to a temporary custody order and the mother’s work schedule) are not material changes warranting modification and reverses the change of custody. Thus, the case does not stand for the proposition that newly acquired stability or fitness may constitute a material change; it rejects the changes asserted here as insufficient.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle … whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’… We note, first, that a parent who works outside the home, even one with a ‘hectic’ schedule, may still be the appropriate primary caretaker and that, standing alone, such employment would not warrant a custody modification… Thus, to the extent that changes in the mother’s work schedule did occur, they were not changes warranting a modification in the custody arrangement.”}

*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.proposition: The Mother’s demonstration of improved housing, educational attainment, and work stability presents precisely the type of changed circumstances recognized in *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (1981), as sufficient to revisit custody and parenting‑time arrangements.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.support_reasoning: Schuler is an alimony/child-support modification case focused on the payor’s income, earning capacity, and assets. It does not involve custody or parenting time, nor does it discuss a custodial parent’s improved housing, education, or work stability as a basis to revisit custody. Citing Schuler for the proposition that such improvements are the kind of changed circumstances sufficient to modify custody/parenting time misstates the scope and subject of the decision.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment… In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances… The needs of the children, the financial status of the support provider, and the station in life of the respective parties must all be considered.”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: Further, persistent conflict or hostility that adversely impacts the child may constitute a material change.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with domestic violence and its effect on custody determinations, but it does not discuss modification standards, "material change of circumstances," or how later-arising persistent conflict/hostility can constitute such a change. The court remands for explicit findings on the impact of domestic violence on the child and appropriateness of the existing custody order; it does not articulate any rule that ongoing conflict or hostility, by itself, constitutes a material change warranting modification. Thus it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: “Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. The very frequency of domestic violence in disputes about child custody may have the effect of inuring courts to it and thus minimizing its significance. Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”

*Draper v. Draper*, 61 Mass. App. Ct. 11.raw_text: *Draper v. Draper*, 61 Mass. App. Ct. 1125 (2004) (Rule 1:28 decision)
*Draper v. Draper*, 61 Mass. App. Ct. 11.proposition: Where one parent’s circumstances materially improve and such improvement would enhance the child’s well‑being, modification may be ordered.
